articles.title: A Proposal to Add Signals to JavaScript
articles.description: A (very) early stage proposal for bringing a new feature to ECMAScript/JavaScript: signals! The proposal brings aboard ideas from a swathe of popular frameworks and aims to align everyone and get us on the same page when it comes to working with state and making updates based upon changes to state. Rob writes more about the proposal here.
articles.author: Rob Eisenberg and Daniel Ehrenberg

articles.title: JS-Torch: A PyTorch-Like Library for JavaScript
articles.description: Python’s PyTorch is one of the gold standards amongst machine learning libraries, but this project brings some of its features directly into the JavaScript world. Here’s a live browser-based demo. Early days but this could become a big deal.
articles.author: Eduardo Leao

articles.title: Bun 1.1 Released: Now Supports Windows Too
articles.description: With the lighthearted codename of Bundows, the alternative server side runtime now runs directly on Windows 10 and up (plus WSL, macOS and Linux, of course). This is a key step in its adoption, with even features like Bun Shell happy on Windows out of the box. Node compatibility continues to improve with support for node:http2 and IPC support between Bun and Node processes.
articles.author: The Entire Bun Team

articles.title: What Even Is a JSON Number?
articles.description: Despite the presence of standards around JSON, the answer is more complicated than you’d think, particularly when it comes to interfacing with other ecosystems and languages that aren’t JavaScript.
articles.author: Brian Terlson

articles.title: The History of JS Interop in Dart
articles.description: About twelve years ago, Google introduced Dart, a language which initially seemed set to take over a lot of JavaScript’s use cases, but which eventually found its own niche (notably with Flutter). JS interoperability has remained important, though, and with Dart 3.3 has gotten significantly better.
articles.author: Sigmund Cherem (Google)

articles.title: The BFCache Explained
articles.description: The back/forward cache (‘bfcache’) is a browser optimization that makes going back and forward in the browser a faster experience – it’s been present for years and usually leaves you alone as a JavaScript developer, but there are things worth being aware of.
articles.author: Sabatino Masala

articles.title: Running OCR Against PDFs and Images Directly in the Browser
articles.description: A look behind the scenes at creating a simple tool using JavaScript to perform OCR against images and PDFs dragged on to the page.
articles.author: Simon Willison

articles.title: Cally: Small, Feature-Rich Calendar Components
articles.description: A collection of open-source calendar components for selecting single dates or date ranges. Framework-agnostic, themeable, localizable, and accessible (it even has an accessibility statement showing its commitment to this area).
articles.author: Nick Williams

articles.title: 📊 Counterscale: Scalable Web Analytics You Can Run on Cloudflare
articles.description: A simple web analytics tracker and dashboard that’s designed to be easy to deploy and maintain by hosting it on Cloudflare (for free too, up to a certain level).
articles.author: Ben Vinegar

articles.title: 🎵 Tonal.js: A Music Theory Library
articles.description: Packed with functions to manipulate tonal elements of music like notes, intervals, chords, scales, modes, and keys, and used as the basis of other music related projects. GitHub repo.
articles.author: danigb

articles.title: Fancy-ANSI: Convert ANSI Text to HTML
articles.description: If, for some reason, you want to convert text with ANSI escape codes into HTML.. Lots of examples on the homepage. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Andres Morey

articles.title: Dioma: Dependency Injection Container for Vanilla JS and TS
articles.description: No decorators, no annotations, no magic, no dependencies – you just add the static scope property to your class and use inject to get an instance.
articles.author: Eugene Daragan

articles.title: svelte-zoomable-circles: Svelte Component for Browsing Hierarchical Data
articles.description: A Svelte component for displaying and browsing hierarchical data using zoomable circles. Live demo.
articles.author: Tyler Berbert

articles.description: Samuel Groß of the V8 team explains the V8 Sandbox, a security mechanism designed to prevent memory corruption in the V8 engine impacting other memory in the process.
Dexie.js is a popular wrapper for IndexedDB and its creator has launched Dexie Cloud, a platform to store and synchronize data between apps.
Svelte's Rich Harris is 'shaken up' after a misunderstanding around 'self-closing' HTML tags and their effect on Svelte.
🤡 There was a curious JS-themed April Fools prank where a .js TLD for domain names was 'announced'. Sadly, it's not true, but there is js.org if you want something vaguely similar.
An official update on the merging of Angular and Wiz.
Deno 1.42 – The alternative JS runtime adds first class support for JSR and improves Node.js compatibility further.
Babylon.js 7 (homepage) – Key release of the popular rendering engine.
Node.js April 3 Security Releases – Includes 18.20.1, 20.12.1 & 21.7.2.
Docusaurus 3.2 – Popular content/docs site generator.
Gulp 5.0

articles.title: An Interactive Guide to CSS Container Queries
articles.description: This is a detailed explainer on CSS container queries, exploring the problems they solve, how they work, and how we can use them in our workflows. Lots of code and visuals to help things along too. Well worth bookmarking.
articles.author: Ahmad Shadeed

articles.title: Introducing Babylon.js 7.0
articles.description: This new version of the popular 3D web rendering engine is now here, adding Apple Vision Pro support, improved WebXR support, improved ragdoll physics, procedural geometry, and more.
articles.author: Babylon.js

articles.title: A Web Designer’s Accessibility Advocacy Toolkit
articles.description: A collection of strategies and selling points to help you encourage and advocate for accessibility in your work, including useful scripts you can use as starting points.
articles.author: Yichan Wang

articles.title: Infinite-Scrolling Logos in Flat HTML and Pure CSS
articles.description: Remember the long-deprecated HTML <marquee> element? If you need a horizontal auto-scrolling solution nowadays, you’ll no doubt turn to CSS. This post demonstrates one technique that uses as little HTML as possible.
articles.author: Sylvester Bistrović

articles.title: 'In-App Browsers are Still a Privacy, Security, and Choice Problem'
articles.description: The Open Web Advocacy (OWA) group wants to prevent in-app browsers from being used to “thwart competition and flout user choice”.
articles.author: Thomas Claburn

articles.title: How to Kill the Cascade
articles.description: “We’ve always needed local resets. And now, with the magic of @scope and all: revert-layer;, we finally have them.”
articles.author: Robin Rendle

articles.title: ▶  Keyboard Interactions
articles.description: Here's a roughly 15-minute talk covering the technical aspects of measuring keyboard interactions in Chromium and how they affect the Interaction to Next Paint metric.
articles.author: Patricija Cerkaite

articles.title: The Curious Case of the CSS Monochrome Media Query
articles.description: This is a little known media-query feature designed to target e-ink devices (such as e-readers), but it seems a tad unloved right now in terms of real-world utilization.
articles.author: Stephanie Stimac

articles.title: Why I Care Deeply About Web Accessibility And You Should Too
articles.description: A web accessibility evangelist makes the case.
articles.author: Schalk Neethling

articles.title: Cally: Small, Feature-Rich Calendar Components
articles.description: A collection of open-source calendar components for selecting single dates or date ranges. Framework-agnostic, themeable, localizable, and accessible. Repo here.
articles.author: Nick Williams

articles.title: Atlassian's Pragmatic Drag and Drop Framework
articles.description: A performance-focused drag and drop library that can be used to power experiences on any frontend stack. There’s a live demo on the page along with ▶️ a recording of a talk by Alex Reardon walking through the motivations for creating it and how it works.
articles.author: Atlassian

articles.title: Journey.js: A Zero-dependency Library to Create Interactive & Accessible Guided Tours
articles.description: The live examples are fairly rudimentary, but the focus on accessibility and built-in support for 51 languages are pluses.
articles.author: William Troup

articles.title: DOM3D.js: A 3D DOM Viewer in a GitHub Gist
articles.description: Some code you can copy and paste into your browser console to get a 3D view of the DOM – sort of (move your pointer to navigate the monstrosity it creates). The effect is very odd at first, but it’s fun to try.
articles.author: Orion Reed

articles.title: <relative-time> 4.4: Format Timestamps as a Localized Relative Time
articles.description: Supply this web component with a standard formatted date and time and it’ll render the right text to suit.
articles.author: GitHub

articles.title: magick.css: A Minimalistic, Mostly Classless CSS Framework
articles.description: See it in action on the author’s website here. It has a ‘brutalist’ look (helped by the font choice) and is inspired by similar ‘classless’ frameworks you may have seen in recent years.
articles.author: Julius Kawatziklis
